questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126 mEq/L, AST: 62, ALT: 56, RBS: 112 mg/dL, and serum bilirubin of 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, diarrhea, bilateral lung infiltrates, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes, Legionella pneumonia should be strongly suspected.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy complains of multiple episodes of acute severe pain in his fingers and toes which resolves on its own for the past 1 year. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Sickle cell anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sickle cell anemia should be suspected in patients who present with episodic acute pain in the extremities, a symptom commonly resulting from vaso-occlusive crises due to abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells blocking blood flow.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about function of utricle and saccule? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Linear acceleration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The utricle and saccule are essential for detecting linear movements, helping the body maintain balance and posture in response to everyday activities and motion, while the cochlea and semicircular canals perform separate functions related to hearing and angular motion detection, respectively.

questions.text: Which form of vitiligo is initially progressive and later becomes stable and non-progressive? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Segmental

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Segmental vitiligo is characterized by its initial rapid progression confined to a segmental area, followed by stabilization and lack of further progression, distinguishing it from other forms of vitiligo that can remain progressive.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided by a patient of fish odor syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Choline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is a metabolic syndrome caused by abnormal excretion of trimethylamine in the breath, urine, sweat, saliva and vaginal secretions . Trimethylamine is derived from the intestinal bacterial degradation of foods rich in choline and carnitine and is normally oxidized by the liver to odorless trimethylamine N-oxide which is then excreted in the urine. Impaired oxidation of trimethylamine due to the deficiency of flavin containing mono oxygenase 3 (FMO3 ) is thought to be the cause of the fish odor syndrome and is responsible for the smell of rotting fish.
  • ➤ caused by abnormal excretion of trimethylamine in the breath, urine, sweat, saliva and vaginal secretions
  • ➤ due to the deficiency of flavin containing mono oxygenase 3 (FMO3
  • ➤ Foods like eggs, liver, peanuts, meat, poultry, fish, dairy foods, pasta and rice are to be avoided.

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Kroner’s procedure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fimbriectomy is a method of tubal ligation where the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. This technique is also known as Kroner’s procedure.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Pomeroy technique : In this method, the mid-isthmic portion of the Fallopian tube is elevated and then folded at the midpoint. One or two rapidly absorbable sutures are tied around the double thickness of the tube, and the folded portion is excised sharply.
  • • Option A. Pomeroy technique
  • • Option B. Uchida's procedure : This involves ligating and excising the midportion of the Fallopian tube. The utero-tubal serosa is then hydro-dissected, and the proximal tubal stump is pulled into the mesosalpinx. The peritoneum is closed over the proximal cut end of the tube.
  • • Option B. Uchida's procedure
  • • Option D. Irving's procedure : In this method, the midportion of the Fallopian tube is ligated and excised. The proximal tubal stump is inserted into an incision made into the myometrium and securely sutured to bury the proximal stump in the myometrium.
  • • Option D. Irving's procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fimbriectomy, also known as Kroner's procedure, involves ligation and excision of the fimbriated end of the Fallopian tube.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.correct_answer: D. MCA doppler peak systolic velocity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain. This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies. MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.
  • • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Biophysical Profile : Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment
  • • Option A. Biophysical Profile
  • • Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis : This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs
  • • Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis
  • • Option C. Amnio-spectrometry : This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.
  • • Option C. Amnio-spectrometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of beta thalassemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, she develops anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next step?

options.label: B
options.text: Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization

options.label: C
options.text: Do clerical work and check ECG

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The development of anxiety, hypotension, and fever during a blood transfusion indicates a possible acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening reaction often due to ABO incompatibility. The immediate and most critical step in managing this reaction is to stop the transfusion immediately.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization : This may be considered in mild allergic reactions with symptoms like urticaria and itching, but not in the presence of hypotension and fever.
  • • Option B. Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization
  • • Option C. Do clerical work and check ECG : These are part of the subsequent steps, but the immediate action is to stop the transfusion.
  • • Option C. Do clerical work and check ECG
  • • Option D. Administer Hydrocortisone : This may be appropriate for mild allergic reactions but is not the first line of action in suspected severe transfusion reactions.
  • • Option D. Administer Hydrocortisone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In any suspected severe transfusion reaction, immediately stop the transfusion to prevent further complications.
  • ➤ In any suspected severe transfusion reaction, immediately stop the transfusion to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is having tapping movements and lack of attention. He seems to be irritated, disturbing others, and restless most of the time. What should be the drug to be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methylphenidate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for managing ADHD in children six years and older due to its effectiveness in reducing symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity.

  • ➤ P
  • ➤ S
  • ➤ S

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 6-year-old male who presents with a midline neck swelling that moves upward with the protrusion of the tongue?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sistrunk operation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sistrunk operation is the treatment of choice for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the removal of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid bone, and the tract to the base of the tongue.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: Which of the following is recommended by the WHO for the management of the second stage of labor? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Manual perineal support and warm compresses

options.label: C
options.text: Maintain head in deflexion and deliver

questions.correct_answer: B. Manual perineal support and warm compresses
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Manual perineal support and warm compresses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Manual perineal support and warm compresses are recommended by the WHO to reduce perineal trauma during the second stage of labor.

questions.text: The first organ to undergo Rigor mortis amongst the following options is: ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myocardium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to Nysten's law, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium (heart muscle) among the listed options.
  • ➤ Rigor mortis follows the “rule of 12”- 12 hrs. to set in, remains for 12 hrs., and passes off in 12 hrs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought after a fall. He has a fever and confusion. On examination, he had a cough with rales. The patient was also tachypneic. How will you manage this patient? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Treat at home with oral Amox-clav

options.label: D
options.text: Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

questions.correct_answer: D. Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Admit and give IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is likely suffering from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and presents with confusion, fever, cough with rales, and tachypnea. Given his age (65 years) and symptoms, a CURB-65 score calculation is necessary. The CURB-65 score assigns points based on confusion, urea level, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age ≥ 65. Here, the patient scores at least 3 points (confusion, tachypnea, age ≥ 65), indicating a need for hospital admission and potentially ICU care.
  • • In managing CAP with a high CURB-65 score, empirical antibiotic therapy typically includes a combination of a beta-lactam (like ceftriaxone) and a macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone (like levofloxacin). This combination is chosen to cover the most common pathogens, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and atypical bacteria.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin: Levofloxacin alone is a potent respiratory fluoroquinolone but may not provide sufficient broad-spectrum coverage
  • • Option A. Admit and give IV levofloxacin:
  • • Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav: Given the patient's high CURB-65 score, home treatment is inappropriate. Oral antibiotics like Amox-clav are insufficient for severe CAP needing hospitalization.
  • • Option B. Treat at home with oral Amox-clav:
  • • Option C. Admit and give IV ceftriaxone: While IV ceftriaxone is effective against many CAP pathogens, the addition of IV levofloxacin provides better coverage, especially for atypical organisms.
  • • Option C. Admit and give IV ceftriaxone:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients with high CURB-65 scores and suspected severe community-acquired pneumonia, hospital admission and combination antibiotic therapy (such as IV ceftriaxone and IV levofloxacin) are essential for effective management.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Sebaceous cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
  • ➤ Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carnitine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.
  • ➤ Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: PET scan is based on: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose metabolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PET scans are based on glucose metabolism , utilizing 18F-FDG to detect areas of high metabolic activity, particularly in cancer cells.
  • ➤ glucose metabolism

questions.text: A 6-week-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent projectile vomiting. USG of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting in an infant around 6 weeks of age, and is best diagnosed with an ultrasound showing thickened pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most radiosensitive? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Testis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The testis is highly radiosensitive due to the high rate of cell division in germ cells, making it more susceptible to radiation compared to other tissues listed.

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines McNaughten's rule? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Section 84 of IPC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Section 84 of IPC defines the act of a person of unsound mind and is derived from the McNaughten Rule, providing a legal defense for individuals who commit crimes due to their mental incapacity.

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hyperlipidemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) LDLr

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mutations in the LDL receptor (LDLr) gene cause familial hypercholesterolemia, a condition characterized by high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood due to impaired clearance by the liver. This condition significantly increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases.

questions.text: Identify the image and make the diagnosis (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichobezoar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A trichobezoar is a ball of hair that accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract due to the compulsive eating of hair (trichophagia) in patients with trichotillomania, and can cause acute abdominal pain due to obstruction.

questions.text: As the member of a school health committee, you are revising the school health program to improve student well-being. Which of the following is NOT a standard component of school health? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Doctor on school premises

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ School Health Program includes:
  • ➤ School Health Program includes:
  • ➤ Screening of general health assessment of visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up etc. First-aid and emergency care Education of handicapped children Health education Maintenance and use of school health records
  • ➤ Screening of general health assessment of visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up etc.
  • ➤ First-aid and emergency care
  • ➤ Education of handicapped children
  • ➤ Health education
  • ➤ Maintenance and use of school health records

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of abdominal pain. Further workup showed elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which investigation should be done next? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tc-99m sestamibi scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with elevated PTH levels and clinical features suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, such as renal calculi, the Tc-99m sestamibi scan is the preferred investigation to localize a parathyroid adenoma.

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Stop the drug and proceed drug free

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are
  • ➤ The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are
  • ➤ A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids. Increased numbers of red blood cells, Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs, Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants
  • ➤ A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  • ➤ Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  • ➤ Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  • ➤ Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  • ➤ Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  • ➤ Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

questions.text: Which of the following stains cause brown color to Her 2 neu cells of breast carcinoma as shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Diamino benzidene

questions.text: A lactating mother who follows a strict vegetarian diet presents with fatigue, weakness, and numbness in her extremities. Upon examination, her blood work reveals a decreased total iron binding capacity. Which of the following deficiencies can cause this clinical picture? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency should be considered in individuals with a strict vegetarian diet presenting with symptoms of megaloblastic anemia (fatigue, weakness) and progressive peripheral neuropathy (numbness in extremities).

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1

options.label: B
options.text: A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

options.label: C
options.text: A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin

options.label: D
options.text: A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH) : Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.
  • • A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH)
  • • B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH) : GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.
  • • B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH)
  • • C. Growth Hormone (GH) : GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.
  • • C. Growth Hormone (GH)
  • • D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1) : IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.
  • • D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1)
  • • The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.
  • ➤ Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: At what pressure is the pop-up valve released in bag and mask ventilation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 30-40 cm of H2O

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pop-up valve in bag and mask ventilation releases at a pressure of 30-40 cm of H2O to prevent excessive pressure that could harm the patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. PET CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A PET CT scan is crucial for the integrated assessment of anatomical and metabolic information, particularly useful in oncology for identifying and tracking the behavior of tumors based on their glucose metabolism, as visualized through radiotracer uptake.

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.
